revision.text:
{{Infobox military unit |unit_name=766th Infantry Regiment |image=[[File:P'ohang-dong Map 1.jpg|250px|alt=A map showing three large divisions of troops advancing through a line of opposing troops to the south]] |caption=Map of the 766th Independent Infantry Regiment's final offensive action, August 10, 1950 |dates=April 1949 – August 19, 1950 |country={{flagicon|North Korea}} [[North Korea]] |allegiance=[[File:Flag_of_the_Korean_People's_Army_Ground_Force.svg|20px]] [[Korean People's Army]] |branch=[[File:Flag_of_the_Korean_People's_Army_Ground_Force.svg|20px]] [[Korean People's Army Ground Force]] |type= [[Infantry]] |role=[[Amphibious warfare|Amphibious]]/[[Commando]] operations |size= [[Regiment]] |command_structure= |notable_commanders=Senior Colonel [[O Chin-u|Oh Jin Woo]] |garrison=[[Hoeryong]], [[North Korea]] |ceremonial_chief= |colonel_of_the_regiment= |nickname= |patron= }}
The '''766th Independent Infantry Regiment''' ({{lang-ko|제766독립보병연대}}) was a [[light infantry]] [[regiment|unit]] of [[North Korea]]'s [[Korean People's Army]] (KPA) that existed briefly during the [[Korean War]]. It was headquartered in [[Hoeryong]], North Korea, and was also known as the '''766th Unit''' ({{lang-ko|766부대}}). Trained extensively in [[amphibious warfare]] and [[unconventional warfare]], the 766th Regiment was considered a [[special forces]] [[commando]] unit. The regiment was trained to conduct assaults by sea and then to lead other North Korean units on offensive operations, to infiltrate behind enemy lines and to disrupt enemy supplies and communications.
Activated in 1949, the regiment trained for more than a year before the outbreak of the war on June 25, 1950. On that day, half of the regiment led North Korean forces against South Korean troops by land and sea, pushing them back after several days of fighting. Over the next six weeks the regiment advanced slowly down the [[Korean Peninsula]], acting as a forward unit of the North Korean army. Suffering from a lack of supplies and mounting casualties, the regiment was committed to the [[Battle of Pusan Perimeter]] as part of a push to force [[United Nations]] (UN) troops out of Korea.
The regiment saw its final action at the [[Battle of P'ohang-dong]], fighting unsuccessfully to take the town from [[U.N.]] troops. Racked by [[U.N.]] naval and air forces and suffering extensive losses from continuous fighting, the regiment was forced to retreat from the P'ohang-dong battlefield. It moved north, joining a concentration of other KPA units, before being disbanded and absorbed into the KPA's [[NK 12th Division|12th Division]].
== Organization == Upon creation, the 766th Unit was designed to vary in size, consisting of a number of smaller units capable of acting alone.<ref name="Mil49"/> Eventually, it was reinforced to the size of a full regiment, with 3,000 men equally distributed across six [[battalion]]s (numbered 1st through 6th). It was made directly subordinate to the KPA Army headquarters<ref name="Mil147"/> and put under the command of [[Senior Colonel]] Oh Jin Woo, who would command the unit for its entire existence.<ref name="Mil336"/> All 500 men of the 3rd Battalion were lost just before the war started when their transport was [[Battle of Pusan|sunk while attacking Pusan harbor]] by the [[Republic of Korea Navy]].<ref name="Rottman167"/><ref name="Rottman171"/> For the remainder of its existence the regiment was whittled down by losses until it numbered no more than 1,500 men and could not muster more than three battalions.<ref name="Apple332"/>
== History == === Origins === During the planning for the invasion of [[South Korea]] in the years before the war, the North Korean leadership began to create large numbers of commando and special forces units to send south. These units subverted South Korean authority before and during the war with [[revolutionary terror|terror campaigns]], sabotage and inducing rebellions in ROK military units. Hundreds of commandos were sent to South Korea in this fashion, and by the end of the war up to 3,000 of them had been trained and armed.<ref name="Mil52">{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=52}}</ref> During this time, North Korean leadership also ordered the creation of large conventional units to act as advance forces for the actual invasion. The 766th Unit was formed in April 1949 at the Third Military Academy in [[Hoeryong]], [[North Korea]]. The academy was specially designed to train commandos, and the 766th was originally designed to supervise North Korean [[light infantry]] ranger units.<ref name="Mil49">{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=49}}</ref> Over the next year, the 766th Unit received extensive training in [[unconventional warfare]] and [[amphibious warfare]].<ref name="Mil52"/> During this time, the unit was expanded in size to 3,000 men in six battalions.<ref name="Mil147">{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=147}}</ref>
Prior to the beginning of the war in June 1950, the 766th completed training and was moved to the front at [[Yangyang]] to support the KPA's [[5th Division (North Korea)|5th Division]].<ref name="Apple27">{{harvnb|Appleman|1998|p=27}}</ref> The North Korean plan was to conduct amphibious landings in [[Jeongdongjin|Chongdongjin]] and Imwonjin on the eastern coast using the 766th Regiment, in conjunction with the [[549th Unit]]. These amphibious landings would harass the rear area of the [[Republic of Korea Army]], providing supporting attacks to the planned frontal attack by the KPA's [[NK II Corps|II Corps]] directly from the north.<ref>{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=118}}</ref> The 766th was in position by June 23 and prepared for the attack.<ref>{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=125}}</ref> The unit was moved to the ports of [[Wonsan]] and [[Kansong]] and loaded into ships.<ref>{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=124}}</ref> With the 3,000 men in the 766th, another 3,000 in the 549th, and 11,000 men in the KPA's 5th Division, the 17,000 North Korean troops outnumbered the [[Republic of Korea Army]]'s (ROK) [[ROK 8th Division|8th Division]]'s 6,866 by a ratio of 2.1 to 1.<ref name="Mil147"/> The combination of the frontal attack and the landings were expected to crush the ROK division and prevent reinforcements from moving in to support it.<ref>{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=209}}</ref>
The regiment was split into three groups for the attack. Three battalions acted as [[spearheads]] for the 5th Division on land while two more battalions conducted the landings in Imwonjin.<ref name="Apple28"/> This 2,500 man force reassembled and then led the North Korean units south.<ref name="Rottman167">{{harvnb|Rottman|2001|p=167}}</ref> In the meantime, the 3rd Battalion, 766th Regiment was detached and sent on a mission to infiltrate Pusan.<ref name="Apple28">{{harvnb|Appleman|1998|p=28}}</ref> Paired with additional support, it formed the 600-man 588th Unit.<ref name="Millett91"/> 588th Unit was tasked with raiding Pusan harbor, destroying vital facilities to make it impossible for UN forces to land troops there.<ref name="Millett92">{{harvnb|Millett|2010|p=92}}</ref> However, the troop transport carrying the 588th Unit was discovered and sunk by United Nations ships outside Pusan harbor the morning of June 25, destroying the 3rd Battalion.<ref name="Rottman171">{{harvnb|Rottman|2001|p=171}}</ref>
=== Outbreak === Around 04:00 on June 25, the KPA's 5th Division began its first attacks on the ROK 10th Regiment's forward positions.<ref name="Alex52">{{harvnb|Alexander|2003|p=52}}</ref> Three hours later, the 766th Regiment's two battalions landed at the village of Imwonjin, using motor and sail boats to land troops and mustering South Korean villagers to assist in setting up supplies. The two battalions separated; one headed into the [[T'aeback Mountains]] and the second advanced north toward [[Samcheok]]. At this point, the ROK 8th Division, under heavy attack from the front and aware of attacks in the rear, urgently requested reinforcements. It was denied these reinforcements, as ROK higher commanders informed the division commander that the ROK Army was under heavy attack across the entirety of the [[38th parallel north|38th parallel]]<ref>{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=210}}</ref> and had no reinforcements to spare.
The ROK 21st Regiment, 8th Division's southernmost unit, moved to counter the amphibious attack. The regiment's 1st Battalion moved from Bukp'yong into the Okgye area and ambushed forward elements of the 766th in conjunction with local police and militia forces. They were able to drive back the 766th Regiment's northern advance.<ref>{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=212}}</ref> However, at least one of the 766th Regiment's battalions massed at Bamjae, blocking one of the 8th Division's main supply routes.<ref>{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=213}}</ref> ROK troops mustered a civilian militia to help fight the North Koreans, which was only moderately effective.<ref name="Millett91">{{harvnb|Millett|2010|p=91}}</ref> The embattled ROK 8th Division was forced to withdraw under overwhelming attacks and breakdowns in communication on July 27. With the retreat of the [[ROK 6th Division]], the entire ROK eastern flank was forced back.<ref>{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=218}}</ref> The 766th Regiment had been successful in establishing a [[bridgehead]] and disrupting communications in the initial attack.<ref>{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=411}}</ref>
=== Advance === [[File:Pusan Perimeter.jpg|thumb|250px|Tactical map of the Pusan Perimeter in August 1950 showing the North Korean advance|alt=A map of a perimeter on the southeastern tip of a land mass]] With the ROK army in retreat, the 766th Regiment, 549th Unit, and KPA's 5th Divisions all advanced steadily south along the eastern roads without encountering much resistance.<ref name="Apple105"/><ref name="Alex74"/> Across the entire front the North Korean Army had successfully routed the South Koreans and was pushing them south.<ref name="Alex52"/> The 766th Regiment acted as an advance force, attempting to infiltrate further inland as it moved through the mountainous eastern region of the country.<ref>{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=275}}</ref> The rugged terrain of the eastern regions of Korea, poor communication equipment, and unreliable resupply lines thwarted the South Korean resistance. The North Koreans used this to their advantage in advancing but they began to experience the same problems themselves.<ref name="Apple105">{{harvnb|Appleman|1998|p=105}}</ref> The 5th Division and the two other units began advancing south slowly and cautiously, sending strong reconnaissance parties into the mountains to ensure they would not be threatened from the rear. However, this more cautious advance began to give the South Koreans valuable time to build up further south.<ref name="Apple106"/> By June 28, the 766th had infiltrated into Taebaek-san from [[Uljin]] and was moving toward [[Ilwolsan]], Yongyang and [[Cheongsong]] in order to block communications between [[Daegu]] and [[Busan]], where [[United States Army]] forces were landing in an attempt to support the collapsing ROK Army.<ref name="Mil336">{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=336}}</ref>
The ROK 23rd Regiment of the [[ROK 3rd Division]] was moved to block the advance of the three units at Uljin. The ROK forces mounted a series of delaying actions against the main North Korean force, which was significantly dispersed throughout the mountainous region and unable to muster its overwhelming strength. The ROK regiment was subsequently able to hold up the North Korean advance until July 5.<ref>{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=340}}</ref> On July 10, the 766th separated from the 5th Division and met an advance party of North Korean civilians in Uljin who had been sent to set up government in the area. From here, the 766th dispersed in small groups into the mountains.<ref name="Apple106">{{harvnb|Appleman|1998|p=106}}</ref> On July 13 it reached Pyonghae-ri, {{convert|25|mi}} north of [[Yeongdeok|Yongdok]].<ref name="Alex74">{{harvnb|Alexander|2003|p=74}}</ref>
Over the next week the 766th Regiment and the KPA's 5th Division continued in a slow advance south as it met increasing South Korean resistance. [[United Nations]] air support began to increase, slowing the advance further. The force continued to occupy the eastern flank, and by July 24 it was advancing from the Chongsong-[[Andong]] region and approaching [[Pohang]]. On its flank was the KPA's [[NK 12th Division|12th Division]].<ref>{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=392}}</ref> Progress halted as UN aerial and naval bombardment made movement more difficult. At the same time the North Korean units' supply lines were stretched thin and began to break down, forcing them to conscript South Korean civilians to carry supplies.<ref>{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=396}}</ref>
=== Resistance === {{main|Battle of Pusan Perimeter}} On July 17, the KPA's 5th Division entered [[Yeongdeok County|Yongdok]], taking the city without much resistance before fierce UN air attacks caused the division heavy losses. Still, it was able to surround the ROK 3rd Division in the city. By now, the 5th Division and the 766th Regiment had been reduced to a combined strength of 7,500 men to the ROK 3rd Divisions' 6,469.<ref>{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=439}}</ref><ref name="Alex109"/> The 766th massed its force again to assist the 5th Division in surrounding and besieging the ROK 3rd Division, which was trapped in the city.<ref name="Apple255">{{harvnb|Appleman|1998|p=255}}</ref> The 3rd Division, in the meantime, was ordered to remain in the city to delay the North Koreans as long as possible. It was eventually evacuated by sea after delaying North Korean forces for a considerable time.<ref>{{harvnb|Millett|2010|p=199}}</ref> The rugged terrain of the mountains prevented the North Korean forces from conducting the enveloping maneuvers they had used so effectively against other troops, and their advantages in numbers and equipment had been negated in the fight.<ref name="Alex116"/>
By July 28, the division was still embroiled in this fight and the 766th bypassed it and moved toward Chinbo on the left flank of the city.<ref name="Mil400"/> However the 766th had suffered significant setbacks at Yongdok, with substantial losses due to American and British naval artillery fire.<ref name="Alex116">{{harvnb|Alexander|2003|p=116}}</ref> Once it arrived in the area, it met heavier resistance from [[South Korean police]] and militia operating in armored vehicles. With air support, they offered the heaviest resistance the unit had faced thus far. With the support of only one of the 5th Division's regiments, the 766th was unable to sustain its advance, and had to pull back by the 29th.<ref name="Mil400">{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=400}}</ref> Movement from the [[ROK Capital Division]] prevented the 766th Regiment from infiltrating further into the mountains.<ref>{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=401}}</ref> ROK cavalry and civilian police then began isolated counteroffensives against the 766th.<ref name="Millett195">{{harvnb|Millett|2010|p=200}}</ref> These forces included special counter-guerrilla units targeting the 766th and countering its tactics.<ref name="Millett2010">{{harvnb|Millett|2010|p=194}}</ref> South Korean troops halted the advance of the North Koreans again around the end of the month thanks to increased reinforcements and support closer to the Pusan Perimeter logistics network.<ref name="Millett195"/>
On August 5, the KPA's 12th Division pushed back the ROK Capital Division in the Ch'ongsong-[[Kigye]] area, and linked up with elements of the 766th which had infiltrated the area of Pohyunsan. Unopposed, they began to prepare to attack P'ohang to secure entry into the UN's newly established [[Pusan Perimeter]].<ref>{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=493}}</ref> The Regiment was ordered to begin an attack in coordination with the KPA's 5th Division. The Korean People's Army planned [[Battle of Pusan Perimeter|simultaneous offensives]] across the entire Perimeter,<ref name="Apple255"/> including a flanking maneuver by the 766th and the 5th Division to [[envelop]] UN troops and push them back to Pusan.<ref name="Alex108">{{harvnb|Alexander|2003|p=108}}</ref> The 766th was not reinforced; North Korean planners intended it to move unseen around the UN lines while the majority of the UN and North Korean troops were locked in fighting around [[Battle of Taegu|Taegu]] and the [[First Battle of Naktong Bulge|Naktong Bulge]].<ref name="Alex109">{{harvnb|Alexander|2003|p=109}}</ref>
By this time, however, North Korean logistics had been stretched to their limit, and resupply became increasingly difficult.<ref name="Alex135"/> By the beginning of August, the North Korean units operating in the area were getting little to no food and ammunition supply, instead relying on captured UN weapons and foraging for what they could find. They were also exhausted from over a month of advancing, though morale remained high among the 766th troops.<ref name="Apple333">{{harvnb|Appleman|1998|p=333}}</ref> The 766th Regiment specialized in raiding UN supply lines, and effectively mounted small disruptive attacks against UN targets to equip themselves.<ref name="Millett164">{{harvnb|Millett|2010|p=164}}</ref>
=== Disbandment === {{main|Battle of P'ohang-dong}} At dawn on August 11, one 300-man battalion<ref name="Apple327">{{harvnb|Appleman|1998|p=327}}</ref> of the 766th Regiment entered the village of P'ohang, creating a state of alarm among its populace.<ref name="Alex135">{{harvnb|Alexander|2003|p=135}}</ref> The village was only protected by a small force of South Korean Navy, Air Force and Army personnel comprising the rear guard of the ROK 3rd Division. The South Korean forces engaged the 766th forces around the village's middle school with [[small-arms]] fire until noon. At that point, North Korean armored vehicles moved in to reinforce the 766th troops and drove the South Koreans out of the village.<ref name="Mil497">{{harvnb|Millett|2000|p=497}}</ref>
[[File:South Koreans at Pusan.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Lines of troops marching along a road|South Korean troops move to reinforce the front lines of the Pusan Perimeter]] The village was strategically important because it was one of the few direct routes through the mountains and into the [[Gyeongsang]] plain. It also led directly to the land routes being used by the UN to reinforce Taegu.<ref name="Apple320">{{harvnb|Appleman|1998|p=320}}</ref> Upon hearing of the fall of P'ohang, UN [[Eighth United States Army]] commander [[Lieutenant General (US)|Lieutenant General]] [[Walton Walker]] immediately ordered naval and air bombardment of the village. He also ordered ROK and US forces to secure regions around the village to prevent further advance of the North Korean troops.<ref name="Mil497"/> Within a few hours, the village was being blasted by artillery forcing the Regiment's advance force to pull back.<ref name="Apple327"/> The 766th's forces congregated and fought in the hills around the village.<ref name="Alex135"/> They joined elements of the KPA's 5th Division, and did not enter P'ohang until night.<ref name="Apple327"/>
UN forces responded to the threat with overwhelming numbers. A large force of South Korean troops, designated Task Force P'ohang, was massed and sent into P'ohang-dong to engage the 766th Regiment and the 5th Division.<ref name="Apple331">{{harvnb|Appleman|1998|p=331}}</ref> ROK troops attacked toward An'gang-ni to the east, forcing the KPA's 12th Division into a full retreat. Threatened with encirclement, the KPA's 5th Division and 766th Regiment were ordered into full retreat on August 17. By this time, the 766th had been reduced to 1,500 men, half its original strength.<ref name="Apple332">{{harvnb|Appleman|1998|p=332}}</ref>
Exhausted and out of supplies, the 766th Regiment moved to Pihak-san, a mountain {{convert|6|mi}} north of Kigye, to join the shattered KPA's 12th Division. The 12th Division was reduced to 1,500 men in the fighting, and 2,000 army replacements and South Korean conscripts were brought to replenish the division. The 766th Regiment was also ordered to merge its remaining troops into the depleted KPA's 12th Division. Upon the completion of the merger with the 12th Division on August 19, 1950, the 766th Regiment ceased to exist. It had trained for close to 14 months prior to the war but fought for less than two.<ref name="Apple332"/><ref name="Rottman166">{{harvnb|Rottman|2001|p=166}}</ref>
==See also== ''[[71: Into the Fire]]'', a 2010 South Korean war film based on the battle of P'ohang-dong
== Notes == {{reflist|colwidth=17em}}
== References == {{refbegin|30em}} *{{citation|first=Bevin |last=Alexander |authorlink=Bevin Alexander |title=Korea: The First War We Lost |publisher=[[Hippocrene Books]] |year=2003 |isbn=978-0-7818-1019-7 |location=[[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]]}} *{{citation|last=Appleman |first=Roy E. |title=South to the Naktong, North to the Yalu: United States Army in the Korean War |url = http://www.history.army.mil/books/korea/20-2-1/toc.htm |year=1998 |publisher=[[Department of the Army]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]] |isbn=978-0-16-001918-0}} *{{citation |last=Millett |first=Allan R. |title=The Korean War, Volume 1 |year=2000 |publisher=[[University of Nebraska]] Press |isbn=978-0-8032-7794-6 |location=[[Lincoln, Nebraska]]}} *{{citation|first=Allan R. |last=Millett |title=The War for Korea, 1950–1951: They Came from the North |publisher=University Press of Kansas |year=2010 |isbn= 978-0-7006-1709-8|location=[[Lawrence, Kansas]]}} *{{citation |last=Rottman |first=Gordon |title=Korean War Order of Battle: United States, United Nations, and Communist Ground, Naval, and Air Forces, 1950–1953 |year=2001 |publisher=[[Praeger Publishers]] |isbn=978-0-275-97835-8 |location=[[Westport, Connecticut]]}} {{refend}} {{featured article}} [[Category:Special forces of North Korea]] [[Category:Infantry regiments of North Korea]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1949]] [[Category:Military units and formations disestablished in 1950]] [[Category:Military units and formations of North Korea in the Korean War|InfReg766]]
